Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Emily Gasser of Yale University to conduct a research project, entitled "Reconstructing Language History in the Pacific with Statistical Modeling," during the summer of 2012 at the University of Auckland in Auckland, New Zealand. The host scientist is Professor Russell Gray.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to contribute to the development of the Austronesian Basic Vocabulary Database and to analyze the data therein using Bayesian phylogeographic methods, thus exploring settlement and migration patterns of the Austronesians into eastern Indonesia and the island Pacific. This project contributes new knowledge concerning the Austronesian language family and more broadly to the field of historical linguistics.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project applied Bayesian phylogenetic methods to two research questions within linguistics, investigating the structure of the Bima-Sumba subgroup of languages spoken in eastern Indonesia and possible relationships between the Tai-Kadai language family, spoken in mainland Southeast Asia, and the Austronesian language family, spoken mainly on the Malay peninsula, island SE Asia, and the Pacific. These internal and external relationships are the subject of ongoing debate within the linguistic communirt. Data from the Austronesian Basic Vocabulary Database (http://language.psy.auckland.ac.nz/austronesian/) was used to infer cognate relationships between individual lexical items in the relevant languages. That cognate coding was then processed using computational models to produce the most likely family trees.

Based on the trees produced by the model, we conclude that when a small group of additional neighboring languages are included, Bima-Sumba is likely to form a single, cohesive subgroup of Austronesian, contrary to some recent proposals. While further work is needed on the Austronesian/Tai-Kadai question, preliminary results suggest that the two families are indeed related, and that Tai-Kadai should be considered a subgroup of Austronesian. These findings provide evidence of the usefulness of these methods within linguistics, and shed light on the history of language change and human migration pattterns throughout the Pacific region.
